SENT.plain: Cerebral emboli identified as high-intensity transient signals (HITS) occur during total knee arthroplasty (TKA)
Their effects on cognitive outcome remain speculative
Intraoperative HITS and postoperative complications were correlated with the cognitive function of TKA patients
Cognitive function was assessed both before and after surgery (1 week and 3 months)
High-intensity transient signals occurred in 22 of 37 patients
Counts of HITSs were higher in patients with sonographically detected intracardiac shunts
Cognitive dysfunction was found in 41% of patients at 1 week, but in only 18% at 3 months
High-intensity transient signal counts were not associated with the prevalence of cognitive deficits
At 1 week, 58% of patients with cognitive deficits had at least 1 postoperative complication (6% in nondeficit patients)
All cognitively impaired patients at 3 months had complications (17% in the nondeficit group)
This raises the possibility that postoperative complications might be associated with cognitive dysfunction in TKA patients
